Award.AwardTitle: Partnership to Improve Student Achievement in Physical Sciences: Integrating STEM Approaches (PISA2)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, led by Stevens Institute of Technology, in partnership with St. Peter's College, Columbia University and 12 geographically, socio-economically and academically diverse school districts throughout New Jersey, aims to improve student achievement in physical sciences in grades 3-8 and increase the quantity, quality and diversity of teachers who are prepared to teach physical science. In addition, the partnership focuses on developing students' 21st century skills, in particular problem-solving, innovation and creativity, by embedding problem-based learning approaches into five new courses in the teacher certification programs. The courses blend engineering design with the mastery of science and mathematics concepts by focusing on three major topic areas as identified by the AAAS Benchmarks for science literacy: the physical setting, the designed world, and the nature of technology. The courses are correlated with the 2009 New Jersey Core Curriculum Content Standards in science, which have an interdisciplinary STEM approach and a problem-based learning emphasis. Each of the five courses will be introduced through the perspective of a contemporary issue in which science and engineering play a paramount role, such as energy consumption and climate change. Scientific inquiry and the engineering design process are embedded within each course and are used as vehicles to promote 21st Century Skills, particularly problem-solving, innovation and creativity.

Over the five years of the project, 400 in-service teachers, 50 STEM undergraduates (preservice teachers) and 120 school and district administrators will benefit from the partnership's primary programs: 1) a new, five-course graduate certificate program, 2) intensive professional development programs leveraging graduate course content, 3) school-year workshops and monthly classroom visits, 4) a Pathways to Teaching Option for science and engineering undergraduates, 5) leadership training/strategic planning/organizational capacity building for district and higher education partners, and 6) science scope & sequence and curriculum workshops.

In addition, the partnership creates an extended faculty community at the lead institution, Stevens Institute of Technology, extending a learning community known as Research & Innovation in Engineering Education, thereby formalizing faculty development pathways to the designation of Master Teacher and providing credit in Stevens' promotion and tenure process for participation in related activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partnership to Improve Student Achievement in Physical Science: Integrating STEM Approaches (PISA2), was a multi-year Math Science Partnership program designed to increase student achievement in science and engineering and student acquisition of 21st century skills, enhance teachers' content and pedagogical practices, and strengthen district leadership and capacity building for science education reform.

Two models of teacher professional development were offered--one preparing teachers through a sequence of five graduate courses (Scholars program) and one preparing teachers to implement strategies to support students' understanding of physical science and engineering concepts (Teacher Leader program). Both programs integrated science inquiry with the engineering design process and were open to teachers in grades 3 through 8.

To maximize program effectiveness, the Scholars program was co-taught by Center for Engineering and Science Education (CIESE) professional development staff and Stevens Institute of Technology Engineering faculty. Teachers enrolled in five graduate science courses (e.g., Fundamentals Principles of Physical Science) over two years. Each course was offered through a combination of face-to-face and on-line sessions. In addition, two professional development days and monthly one-on-one coaching visits provided support for classroom implementation. As each course built successively deeper, broader content knowledge for teachers, the Scholars program built teachers' capacity and confidence to master and teach more complex concepts. Teachers who completed the Scholars program earned 15 graduate credits in science, making them eligible for Elementary School Endorsement with Science Specialization in New Jersey.

The Teacher Leader professional development model consisted of: one week-long summer institute focused on specific content areas such as Energy or Force and Motion, two one-day workshops during the school year, and two in-class visits to plan, observe and reflect on implementation strategies. Because the Teacher Leader program overlapped with the release of Next Generation Science Standards, the program highlighted the use of the engineering design process to support physical science learning; claims, evidence and reasoning to link science to literacy (Folkes & Kennedy, 2015; 2016); and use of notebooks to promote student thinking and reasoning.

To sustain the program and its impact on student and teacher learning, PISA2 engaged 12 district partners in leadership training, strategic planning and capacity building. PISA2 worked with the National Science Resources Center to facilitate a sequence of institutes to address critical questions related to research and best practices in K-12 science education. Following A Building Awareness for Reform Symposium, district partners participated in Institutes for Leadership Development and Strategic Planning and yearly Implementation Institutes during which districts reflected on progress towards implementing their strategic plan. Over time, changes in leadership led to fading participation of both district leaders and their teachers in some of the neediest districts.

Intellectual Merit. For the Scholars program, key challenges included teacher expectations that the scholars program would be an enhanced professional development experience and not so heavy on content, teachers' low level math skills that constrained the extent to which some physical science concepts could be taught, and too much content for the length of the course. Feedback from participating teachers and high attrition rates in the first year led to increased use of activities and projects (Camins & Bressler, 2015) and renewed attention to effective strategies for introducing content (Bartus & Fisher, 2015; 2016) and increasing teacher confidence (Bartus, 2017).

For the Teacher Leader program, students and teachers' science learning was positively impacted when engineering design was a key component of science instruction (Macalalag, Lowes, Tirthali, McKay & McGrath, 2010; Macalalag, A.Z. & Jurado, C., 2012). Teachers at all levels of prior knowledge posted gains in content knowledge; this includes teachers in both the Leader program and Scholars program. With respect to instructional practices, teachers increased the number of hands-on science and engineering activities and began to experiment with the targeted practices of using models, the engineering design process, and evidence-based explanation.

Broader Impacts. The overarching goal of the project was to deliver high quality, standards- and research-based STEM programs in 12 partner districts across the state of New Jersey. Together, the teacher professional development programs have impacted 400 grades 3-8 teachers from urban and suburban districts characterized by racial/ethnic diversity and high numbers of economically disadvantaged students. For the Scholars program, 80% of teachers who completed the five-course sequence had taken or planned to take the PRAXIS exam, an important element in the certification process. In addition, all participating faculty incorporated some of the active-learning practices that appealed to teachers into their undergraduate and graduate classes (Camins & Bressler, 2015).

Teacher Leaders' increased knowledge, skill and confidence led to increased: (1) efforts to introduce family engineering or STEM night at their school, (2) opportunities to participate in district curriculum development, (3) presentations at regional conferences, (4) recognition including Teacher of the Year and Einstein Fellowship awards and, (5) offers to lead professional development in their school or district.
